question.title: How do I make a truth table on the Q/A site?

Upload a picture, or a spreadsheet, or use the table tool in the Q/A editor.

question.title: Practice with Number Theory and More Counting!
question.content:
Some of these questions on number theory relate back to the theorems learned in class during the discussion on cryptography.

1. Prove that the number of permutations of n objects, m of which are alike, is $ \frac{n!}{m!}$

2. Supposed that three girls and four boys line up to board a school bus.

a. In how many ways can the seven children line up?

b. In how many of the arrangements in (a) are the three girls first in line?

c. In how many of the arrangements in (a) are the three girls together in line?

d. In how many of the arrangements in (a) are the four boys together in line?

e. In how many of the arrangements in (a) are no two boys together?

3. Prove that for any natural numbers r, n, and m with $ r \le n + m$

$ \binom{n + m}{r} = \binom{n}{0} \binom{m}{r} + \binom{n}{1} \binom{m}{r - 1} + \binom{n}{2} \binom{m}{r - 2} + \cdots + \binom{n}{r} \binom{m}{0}$

4. Prove that for any natural number n , $ \binom{2n}{n} + \binom{2n}{n + 1} = \frac12 \binom{2n + 2}{n + 1}$

 

5. Prove that

a. there exists integers m and n such that 2m + 7n = 1;

b. there do not exist integers m and n such that 2m + 4n = 7.

6. Prove that if every even natural number greater than 2 is the sum of two primes, then every odd natural number greater than 5 is the sum of three primes.

7. Prove that if p is a prime number and $ p \ne 3$, then 3 divides $ p^2 + 2$.

8. Prove that the conjugate of the sum of any two complex numbers is the sum of their conjugates.

9. Let a, b, and c, be positive integers. Prove that

a. if ab = 1, then a = 1 and b = 1.

b. if a divides b and b divides a,  then a = b.

c. if ac  divides bc, then a divides b.

10. Let x and y be positive real numbers. Prove that $ \frac{x + y}{2} \ge \sqrt{xy}$.

11. Suppose a right triangle has hypotenuse c and legs a and b. Prove that the triangle is isosceles if and only if its area is $ \frac14 c^2$

12. Prove that $ \sqrt{2}$ is irrational.

question.title: Show that irrational numbers behave irrationally, in the sense that their fractional parts show up all over the real interval [0,1]?
question.content:
A mathematical example to prove:  For these questions, let [x] denote the fractional part of x: that is, $ {[x]=x-\lfloor x\rfloor}$. We are going to look at the set of all fractional parts, $ {F_{\alpha}=\{[na]\mid\forall n\in I\!\!N\}}$.  Recall that a number $ \alpha$ is irrational iff there do not exist integers $ p,q$ satisfying $ {\alpha=p/q}$.  Show the following:
  1. For any irrational number $ \alpha$, the elements we put into set $ {F_{\alpha}}$ are distinct. That is, for all positive integers $ m,n\in I\!\!N$, we have $ {[m\alpha]=[n\alpha]}$ iff $ m=n$.
  2. For any irrational number $ \alpha$, the lower limit $ \inf F_{\alpha} = 0$. That is, for any $ \epsilon>0$, there is an $ n\in I\!\!N$ with $ [n\alpha]<\epsilon$.  (Hint:  Use pigeonhole principle to show that two fractional parts must be close, then subtract them.)
  3. For any irrational number $ \alpha$, the set $ F_{\alpha}$ is \df{dense} in the interval $ [0,1]$. That is, for any reals $ {x\in[0,1]}$ and $ \epsilon>0$, there is an $ n\in I\!\!N$ such that $ {|x-[n\alpha]|<\epsilon}$.
One way to generate pseudo-random numbers is to take the fractional parts of integer multiples of an irrational number.

question.title: Questions about the game SET
question.content:
Here are four questions about the card game SET.

Each card has four features.  According to the rules, there are three choices for each feature.

(C) Number: Each card has one, two, or three symbols.

(D) Shading: Each card is solid, open, or striped.

1. How many cards are in a SET deck?

 

A 'Set' consists of three cards in which each feature is EITHER the same on each card OR is different on each card. (Thus, "If two are... and one is not, then it is not a 'Set'.")  Visit the set rules to see examples of both sets and non-sets.

2. If you choose two cards, how many cards from the SET deck will complete a Set?

 

3. What is the maximum number of cards you can lay out without having a Set among them?

 

4. Can you create a 3×3 square of set cards in which every row, column, and diagonal is a set?  In how many different ways?

question.title: How many simple substitution cyphers on [a-z]?
question.content:
A simple substitution cypher replaces each letter a-z with some other letter in an invertible manner -- it is a bijection from a-z to a-z. You may have seen Cryptoquote in the newspaper, for which the standard example is AXYDLBAAXR = LONGFELLOW (i.e., a-> L and x-> O.)

How many different simple substitution cyphers are there?

Suppose that we want to avoid sending a letter to itself, so we replace letters from the first half (a-m) with letters from the second half (n-z) and vice versa. With this restriction, how many different simple substitution cyphers are there?

Counting the number of substitution cyphers in which no letter maps to itself is not easy, but you can take a swing at that, too.

question.title: How many musical compositions are there?
question.content:
For the musicians: How many choices do you have when making a musical composition?  There are many things that make this question hard (types of instruments, tonal scale, time signature, dynamic range, tempo, chords, rests, slurs, holds, glissandos, ...)  Let's start with simple versions of this question.

Let's say we want to compose an 8-measure theme in 4/4 time, and let ourselves use whole, half, quarter, eighth, and sixteenth notes.  Ignore dynamic range and tempo changes, and fancy trills, slides, etc.  Even for the following simpler questions the answers will not be easy to count.

In fact, let's start with a single tone (middle-C) no rests.  How many different patterns of notes can you have in a single measure?  In eight measures?

 

Now, add the choice of tone for each note (still no rests) .  What expression counts if you can choose your notes from, say, the 88 keys on a piano?

 

If you add rests, observe that consecutive rests (unlike notes of the same tone) may merge into a longer rest. Can we add those to the count?

 

What other variants would you like to count?

question.title: Ways to re-arrange a broken Rubik's cube
question.content:
In another question we saw that a Rubik's cube has 9*6=54 stickers. More importantly, a Rubik's cube has 12+8+6=26 pieces. There are 12 edges of 2 stickers, 8 corners of 3 stickers, and 6 centers of 1 sticker. Note that edges and corners each have specific stickers in a particular order, and that a red-blue edge will always be a red-blue edge no matter how the cube is twisted. This might be more obvious when looking at a sticker-less cube such as this one. 

 

If one had all 26 pieces of the cube, how many different ways could it be put back together? 

Even harder, how does that number decrease when the cube has to be put back into a solvable state? As a hint, note that seven corners may be oriented independently, but the 8th corner depends on the first 7. Similarly, 11 edges may be oriented independently, but the 12 depends on the first 11.  

Harder than that, how does that number change when the centers must be oriented correctly? While not obvious or important for a regular Rubik's cube, for arrow cubes or photo cubes the cube will not be solved until the centers face the correct direction. 

    

 JSS: This question is quite hard if you consider different cubes to be the same if they can be reoriented to look the same, or if they can be shuffled to look the same. Even what you "notice" about the corners is not clear to me.

question.title: How many different completed Sudoku puzzles are there?
question.content:
A Sudoku is a grid with nine rows and nine columns, divided into nine squares, each with three rows and three columns. When completed, a Sudoku puts a digit 1-9 in each grid space such that:

1. Every row contains the numbers 1-9 with no repeats.
2. Each column contains the numbers 1-9 with no repeats.
3. Each 3x3 square contains the numbers 1-9 with no repeats.

For example, here is a completed Sudoku puzzle, stolen shamelessly from Wikipedia:

How many different ways are there to fill this grid with the digits 1-9, such that each row, each column, and each 3x3 square contains each digit exactly once?

JSS: This is quite difficult, so here are some easier subproblems:

  1. How many ways can you fill a 3x3 grid using each of the numbers 1-9?
  2. This means there are how many ways to fill 9 3x3 grids if we didn't worry about repeating numbers in rows and columns?
  3. How many ways can you fill a 9x9 grid so you use a digit at most once in each column? (should be the same as 2).
  4. Is there an easy way to count the number of 9x9 grids that use each digit once in each row and column?  (I'm not sure...) 

NT:  5. Note that most sudoku puzzles have 180 degree rotational symmetry with regards to the locations that initially contain numbers (If the top left corner contains a starting number, so will with bottom right, and so on).  It was finally proven last Sunday that the minimum number of clues needed to solve a sudoku puzzle is 17 (that is, if a puzzle begins with 16 or fewer squares filled in, it is unsolvable.)  How many ways are there to select at least 17 squares in the grid such that the selection has 180 degree rotational symmetry?  How many ways are there to select at least 17 squares with this symmetry and then fill them?

JSS: 6. There is an easy way to get a lower bound on the number of sudokus:  you can choose three diagonal 3x3 grids independently.  In how many ways can you fill those in?  (Demonstrate that you may still have additional choices after you choose what goes in the diagonal 3x3s, so this is only a lower  bound.) 

NT: 7. Can you find an upper bound, using a similar method to the one in 6?

question.title: Induction 33: What happens to a lamb among lions?
question.content:
A lamb wanders into an enclosure of n lions.  What happens?

The lions in the enclosure are hungry, vicious, and solitary,  so each would gladly kill and eat the lamb, and none would cooperate or share.  They are also intelligent and value self-preservation above all.  They know from their feeding rotation that after eating they need a nap, and are vulnerable to the other lions while asleep.  (This is why their keeper takes them one-at-a-time into the small feeding enclosure, where a lion can eat and nap before he returns to the main enclosure.)

Does the lamb get eaten by the nearest of the n lions?  Does the answer depend on n?

JSS: the first four proofs posted here are very similar, and (IMNSHO) all are wrong. Let me add one with a different conclusion.

MH: I think it might be helpful to note that when the prompt says that a lion is "vulnerable" to other lions while asleep, it means that other lions will ATTACK AND EAT A SLEEPING LION. I didn't pick that up the first read through, and that's a pretty important part of this problem.
JSS: one purpose of proof is to reveal which assumptions are being made. Each of the proofs here is based on the assumption that a sleeping lion may be attacked, so that seems to have been the common understanding.  That the attacker of a sleeping lion will itself eat and sleep is my assumption. (If you don't make that assumption, then there is no need for induction, which is why so many of the proofs initially here had the form of induction, but didn't use the IH.)   

----possible rewording---

The lions in the enclosure are hungry, vicious, and solitary,  so each would gladly kill and eat the lamb (or any sleeping lion), and none would cooperate or share. They are also intelligent and value self-preservation above all.  Each know that after it kills and/or eats it needs a nap, and is vulnerable to other lions while asleep.  (The lion keeper feeds one at a time in a small side enclosure, where the fed lion can safely nap before returning to the main enclosure.)

question.title: Induction 36: What happens to the islanders?
question.content:
From http://xkcd.com/blue_eyes.html

Blue Eyes:
The Hardest Logic Puzzle in the WorldA group of people with assorted eye colors live on an island. They are all perfect logicians -- if a conclusion can be logically deduced, they will do it instantly. No one knows the color of their eyes. Every night at midnight, a ferry stops at the island. Any islanders who have figured out the color of their own eyes then leave the island, and the rest stay. Everyone can see everyone else at all times and keeps a count of the number of people they see with each eye color (excluding themselves), but they cannot otherwise communicate. Everyone on the island knows all the rules in this paragraph.

On this island there are 100 blue-eyed people, 100 brown-eyed people, and the Guru (she happens to have green eyes). So any given blue-eyed person can see 100 people with brown eyes and 99 people with blue eyes (and one with green), but that does not tell him his own eye color; as far as he knows the totals could be 101 brown and 99 blue. Or 100 brown, 99 blue, and he could have red eyes.

The Guru is allowed to speak once (let's say at noon), on one day in all their endless years on the island. Standing before the islanders, she says the following:

"I can see someone who has blue eyes."

Who leaves the island, and on what night?

There are no mirrors or reflecting surfaces, nothing dumb. It is not a trick question, and the answer is logical. It doesn't depend on tricky wording or anyone lying or guessing, and it doesn't involve people doing something silly like creating a sign language or doing genetics. The Guru is not making eye contact with anyone in particular; she's simply saying "I count at least one blue-eyed person on this island who isn't me."

And lastly, the answer is not "no one leaves."

----------------

Terry Tao discusses a much more vicious version: 

There is an island upon which a tribe resides. The tribe consists of 1000 people, with various eye colours. Yet, their religion forbids them to know their own eye color, or even to discuss the topic; thus, each resident can (and does) see the eye colors of all other residents, but has no way of discovering his or her own (there are no reflective surfaces). If a tribesperson does discover his or her own eye color, then their religion compels them to commit ritual suicide at noon the following day in the village square for all to witness. All the tribespeople are highly logical and devout, and they all know that each other is also highly logical and devout (and they all know that they all know that each other is highly logical and devout, and so forth).  ["Highly logical" means that any conclusion that can logically deduced from the information and observations available to an islander, will automatically be known to that islander.]

Of the 1000 islanders, it turns out that 100 of them have blue eyes and 900 of them have brown eyes, although the islanders are not initially aware of these statistics (each of them can of course only see 999 of the 1000 tribespeople).

One day, a blue-eyed foreigner visits to the island and wins the complete trust of the tribe.

One evening, he addresses the entire tribe to thank them for their hospitality.

However, not knowing the customs, the foreigner makes the mistake of mentioning eye color in his address, remarking “how unusual it is to see another blue-eyed person like myself in this region of the world”.

What effect, if anything, does this faux pas have on the tribe?

question.title: Induction 39: Can you determine who is a celebrity, if any, with few questions?
question.content:
In a group of n people, a celebrity is a person who everyone else knows, but who doesn't know anyone else.

Lets write $aKb[/latex] iff a knows b, and [latex]a\not\!\! K b[/latex] iff a does not know b.  So [latex]c\in[1..n][/latex] is a celebrity iff [latex]\forall a\in[1..n],\; (a=c)\vee (aKc\wedge c\not\!\!Ka)$.  Can a group have more than one celebrity?

You are an outsider, sent by a news agency, to identify if there is a celebrity at a party of n people.  You want to ask people if they know specific other people, but don't want to annoy and get kicked out, so you want to ask few questions.   There are, of course, (n-1) possible questions per person, for a total of n(n-1).  How few questions do you need to ask to guarantee that you can always identify and confirm the identity of a celebrity, if one exists?  (You cannot ask one person "Do you know anyone here?' without asking them n-1 questions, which is sure to get you kicked out.)

I suggest working the room in two phases: first, start by assuming
that anyone could be a celebrity, and ask questions that try to rule
people out.  Then, when you have single candidate, ask questions to
confirm.

You should be able to use induction to obtain a strategy in which each person, with one possible exception, need be asked at most two questions.

 

No pressure, but your job depends on getting the right answer, so you
must be correct, and want to ask the smallest number of questions possible...

question.title: Induction 31; Can you represent numbers as sets?
question.content:
An interesting recursive way to represent every non-negative integer $n[/latex] as a set [latex]S_n$ is the following:

  • Base: $S_0=\emptyset$ represents 0.
  • Recursive rule: For $n>0[/latex], let [latex]S_n=S_{n-1} \cup\{S_{n-1}\}$ represent n.
  • Closure: All sets representing integers come from the base case, by a finite number of applications of the recursive rule.
 
  1. Show that $S_n[/latex] has [latex]n$ elements.
  2. Show that $i<j[/latex] iff [latex]S_i\subsetneq
    S_j[/latex], that is, [latex]S_i[/latex] is a proper subset of [latex]S_j$.
  3. Show that for $S_i[/latex] and [latex]S_j[/latex] we have three choices: either [latex]S_i\subsetneq S_j[/latex], [latex]S_i=S_j[/latex], or [latex]S_j\subsetneq S_i $.
  4. Recursively define functions for addition and multiplication.

NT: Bonus Round! Can you find another way to represent numbers as sets such that there is a one-to-one correspondence between:

a) The set of non-negative integers

b) The set S defined by:

Base: The empty set {} is in S

Recursive Rule: If every element of x is in S, x is in S.

Closure: Only sets derived from the base case by a finite number of applications of the recursive rule are in S.

Find such a correspondence and prove it's one-to-one! (It exists; I was very bored one weekend.)

question.title: Induction 32: Visit the all the cities served by One-way Airlines?
question.content:
One way Airlines has the peculiar strategy for the set C of all cities they serve:
${\forall a\ne b\in C}[/latex], they guarantee to fly at least one of the routes, [latex]{a\to b}[/latex] or [latex]{b\to a}$.

As a loyal customer, you've won their unlimited trip -- you may visit for free any sequence of cities along routes they fly, ${a\to b\to c\to \cdots}$, as long as you don't interrupt the chain or arrive in or depart from a city more than once.

Can you visit all the cities of C?  Does it matter where you start?  

Note that this will be a proof 'For all route maps on C cities', not just on the number of cities.

question.title: Induction 41: What is this recursively defined function?
question.content:
Here is the recursive definition of a function $f\colon\mathbb{N}\to\mathbb{R}$:

  1. Base:  $f(1)=1$.
  2. Rec. rule: For even n>1,  $f(n)=1+f(n/2)[/latex], and
    For odd n>1,  [latex]f(n)=1+f((n-1)/2)$

What is this function, and can you prove it?

question.title: Induction 35: How many moves to solve the Towers of Hanoi?
question.content: The classic puzzle called the Towers of Hanoi consists of a board with three pegs and several disks of different diameters that fit over the pegs. In the starting position all the disks are in place on one peg, arranged in order of decreasing diameter from bottom to top. A move is made by lifting the top disk off a peg and placing it on another peg so that there is no smaller disk beneath it. The object of the puzzle is to transfer all the disks from one peg to another. Prove by induction that if the number of disks is n, the puzzle can be solved in $ 2^n - 1$ moves.

question.title: Induction 43: Prove this is a fair division of the cake?
question.content:
There are n people dividing a cake.  Each wants to get his or her 'fair share' of 1/n th of the cake (and maybe a bit more).  But of course, some want more icing, some like the candies, some try to avoid the edge---each may have a different idea of what they would most like as their 1/n th of the cake.

So they agree do divide as follows: the oldest starts moving the knife slowly above the cake from one end.  If any younger one says, "Stop," then that end is cut off and given to the speaker.  The knife-wielder can also decide to stop and cut their own piece.  Prove by induction that each person goes away satisfied that they got 1/n of the cake.  

Note: you probably don't want n to be the induction parameter, since the desired fraction of cake doesn't change with the number of people remaining.

question.title: Induction 42: Can you show these numbers are in [1,2)?
question.content:
Here is a recursively defined set S of real numbers:

  1. Base: One is in S: $1 \in S$.
  2. Rec rule:  Square roots of sums and products of numbers in S are in S:
    if ${x,y} \in S[/latex], then [latex]\sqrt{x+y} \in S[/latex] and  [latex]\sqrt{xy} \in S$.
  3. Closure: only numbers derived from the base case by a finite number of applications of the recursive rule are in S.

Show that all numbers in S are within the half-open interval [1, 2).

question.title: Induction 23: Can you always lay out A-K in a 2-suit, back-to-back deck?
question.content: Take the red cards (hearts and diamonds) from a deck, shuffle them, pair them up arbitrarily, then glue pairs back to back. Show that you can still lay out the pairs so that you'll see, face up: A, 2, 3, $\dots$, 10, J, Q, K. (Suits showing does not matter.) We can generalize to a $2n[/latex]-card deck, consisting of [latex]1\dots n$ of hearts and diamonds. Play with a 10 card deck (A..5) on scratch paper until the problem is clear.

question.title: Induction 29: Can you prove Fermat's little theorem by induction?
question.content:
Prove Fermat's little theorem, by induction on $m$:

For all primes $p[/latex] and positive integers [latex]m[/latex], the exponential [latex]m^{p} \bmod p = m\bmod p$.

question.title: Induction 30: Can you prove the Chinese Remainder Theorem?
question.content:
Prove the Chinese remainder theorem:

given integers $ n_1, n_2, \dots ,n_k[/latex] that are pairwise relatively prime (no two have a common factor) and have product [latex]N=\prod_{i\in [1..k]}n_i[/latex], show that any integer [latex]m\in[0,N)[/latex] is uniquely determined by its remainders [latex](m\bmod n_i)_{i\in[1..k]}$.

 

You'll want to choose good notation, use induction on $k$, and use Lemma 7.3.2 within the induction step.
